title: Hypnotism
intro: Either used for treating phobias or just for entertainment, hypnotism has always fascinated us. One question that’s often asked: can anyone be hypnotised or are there people - maybe you - who are less hypnotisable than others? Rob and Sam talk about the topic and teach you related vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: One of the first Europeans to hypnotise people became so famous that his name is forever associated with hypnotic trances – but who was he?
a) Sigmund Freud b) Franz Mesmer c) Harry Houdini
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a state of consciousness in which you are not completely aware or in control of yourself, but in which you can hear and see things and respond to commands given by others
become so occupied with something that you are not sure how much time has passed
become involved in a situation when you do not want to be involved
to give all your attention to something
have your attention completely fixed so that you cannot think of anything else

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Rob.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I’m Sam.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Now, Sam, look into my eyes! You are feeling sleepy! Relax!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: What are you doing, Rob? Trying to hypnotise me?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, since hypnotism is the topic of this programme, I thought I’d give it a try! So how do you feel, Sam? Are you under my spell?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hmmm, I don’t think so, Rob. It’s not so easy to put me into a hypnotic trance – that’s the word to describe the state of mind of someone who’s been hypnotised and isn’t completely in control.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You mean like those stage magicians who trick people into clucking like a chicken or playing an imaginary violin?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Yes, some hypnotists make people do silly things for entertainment but hypnotism has real benefits as well - curing phobias, for example.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Maybe so, but for other people the very idea of a hypnotic trance is nonsense. And even if hypnotism is real, why would you let a complete stranger inside your head?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Don’t worry, Rob. I won’t make you cluck like a chicken!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Please don’t! At least, not before my quiz question, which is about a well-known 20th century hypnotist. One of the first Europeans to hypnotise people, this man became so famous that his name is forever associated with hypnotic trances – but who was he? Was it: a) Sigmund Freud?, b) Franz Mesmer?, or c) Harry Houdini?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Well, people who want to quit smoking sometimes use a kind of therapy involving hypnotism, so maybe it’s a) Sigmund Freud!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, we’ll find out if that’s right at the end of the programme. One question that’s often asked is whether anyone can be hypnotised - or are there people, maybe like you, Sam, who are less hypnotisable than others?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Professor Amir Raz is a psychiatrist at The Brain Institute in Orange County, California. According to him, there are two things which explain what makes one person more or less hypnotisable than another, as he told BBC World Service programme, The Why Factor.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And listen out for the first thing he mentions:

transcript.author: Prof Amir Raz
transcript.text: Initially people thought that if you’re very intelligent you’re likely to be less suggestible ; if you are male you’re likely to be less suggestible than if you’re female; and so on. These have been largely dismissed.

transcript.author: Nicola Kelly
transcript.text: In fact, it’s about two things. First, absorption…

transcript.author: Prof Amir Raz
transcript.text: Your ability to get engrossed in a particular activity – we all know people who are capable of reading a book and losing track of time , we know the same thing about people who are watching a film and beginning to cry, having all these emotional reactions, again getting very much sucked into the scene and being riveted.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: People often think you can be easily hypnotised if you are suggestible ,or easily influenced by others.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: In fact, hypnotism is about two things. Did you hear the first thing, Sam?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Yes - it’s getting absorbed; so absorbed that you lose track of time - become so occupied with something that you are unaware of the passing time.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And getting absorbed can also mean you get sucked into something - become involved in a situation when you do not want to be involved.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Stage hypnotists often speak in a soothing, gentle ways to help this process of getting someone absorbed or sucked in!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But according to Professor Raz, there’s a second important part to being hypnotised: attention.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Listen to the definition of attention Professor Raz gives to BBC World Service programme, The Why Factor:

transcript.author: Prof Amir Raz
transcript.text: The ability to get focused, to concentrate and hone in on particular, select pieces of information to the exclusion of others.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Besides the relaxed, dream-like feeling of being absorbed, what’s also needed is the concentration to hone in on something , in other words, to give it your full attention.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: What you hone in on could be the way the hypnotist speaks, like how Rob said, “Look into my eyes!” at the beginning of the programme.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Or it could be some other object, like a moving finger, a pendulum or a swinging watch that some hypnotists use.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Well, I don’t feel hypnotised, Rob, but I’m certainly focused on one thing – my lunch! So come on, tell me – what's the correct answer to the quiz question?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, Sam. I asked you which hypnotist was so famous that his name became used as a verb. And what did you say?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I guessed it was a) Sigmund Freud.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It was a good guess – but the correct answer was b) a German doctor called, Franz Mesmer.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Of course! And the word named after him was… mesmerised – to have your attention completely fixed so that you can’t think of anything else.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that might be a problem if you want to remember this vocabulary, so let’s recap the words we’ve learned, starting with trance – a state of consciousness in which you are not completely aware or in control.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Someone who is suggestible is easily influenced by other people.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: When you lose track of time , you become so absorbed with something that you are unaware of time passing.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And you might get sucked in - become involved in a situation that you don’t want to.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hypnotism also depends on concentration and the ability to hone in on something - to give something your full attention…

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: …until you’re mesmerised – you have your attention completely fixed so that you cannot think of anything else.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That’s all for this hypnotic journey. Bye for now!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Bye bye!
